instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C
threads.message: I've reballed the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips with no change. I have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. I've looked at everything I can find in the area. The spill wan't too bad, just hit this area a little. <RESISTOR>R3351</RESISTOR> was blown. I replaced that and <TRANSISTOR>Q3350</TRANSISTOR> to be safe. <RESISTOR>R3209</RESISTOR> had a charred pad so I cleaned that off and replaced <RESISTOR>R3209</RESISTOR>. Not sure where to go next. Is it just replace the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C
threads.message:
Did you replace with same termination, i.e. B03, C00?
These chips have frimware!

Check for short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and other rails.
Do you get <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

Check diode mode (red probe at ground) on all power rails of <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C
threads.message: I'd replace both. As 2informaticos said, must be correct firmware.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C
threads.message: Hi, I didn't replace them yet, I just reballed the chips that were on there to see if they might work still. If I replace them can I pull them off any of the MacBook Pros with C00's on them? Also, can I just order and use the C00's from Louis or do I need to program those first? I'll check the other things you mentioned once I'm near the board again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C
threads.message:
Termination code is firmware specific.
So no matters where you get C00.
Buy from Loius and stock them if you don't have scrap boards.
This way you get them reballed and save time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C
threads.message: I've looked everywhere for shorts and can't find any. <CHIP>U8510</CHIP> has <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> coming in at 3.4V. <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is at 0V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C
threads.message: If <CHIP>U8510</CHIP> gets 3.3V at pin 1, then change it; if no <SIGNAL>BUF_SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C
threads.message: Amazing find - bad <CHIP>U8510</CHIP>. Pads were charred underneath it. Has 20V and CPU now after cleaning up the pads and replacing <CHIP>U8510</CHIP>. My <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s were probably fine the whole time. Thanks so much for getting me there. I really wanted to fix this board so I could test the stack of SSD's I have from all of these 00840 boards that had shorted CPU's

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C
threads.message: That's why they pay him the big bucks lol
